pdc_describe.title: Clean out PDC Describe Production to prep for data migration

comments.body:
@carolyncole Great question. I have gone back and forth on this. When I wrote that guide to syncing S3 buckets I was picturing that we would make a new Globus service, spin up an empty S3 bucket for it, and then synch the data. However, the more I understand about our projects and the state of the legacy data the more I lean toward migrating the files one by one. The legacy Globus S3 bucket contains lots of empty folders named with DOIs. That's going to make it very hard to tell when we've correctly migrated any given work. I now believe that a better workflow would be, for each object:

1) Describe the record in pdc_describe
2) Submit the data payload via pdc_describe
  a) via the form for objects < 100Mb
  b) upload directly via Globus or S3 for big data
3) A curator checks the DataCite record that we produce and refines as necessary
4) Upon approval, the data payload is moved to the new S3 bucket and deleted from the legacy location
  a) This will also require indexing into PDC Discovery and updating the download link there
 
QUESTION: Should there also be a step where we manually delete the migrated object from DataSpace? I'd like to, if possible, because it will make it more clear that PDC Describe is the canonical copy, and it would prevent potential snarls where we've already migrated a record but then someone goes in and makes changes to the DataSpace record and those changes aren't persisted to PDC Describe. However, it's hard to advocate for deleting a record from DataSpace before we have very good assurance that PDC Describe is a fully operational production system with reliable backup and restore. So maybe that's a thing to prioritize?

pdc_describe.title: When a work has an existing DOI, redirect it

comments.body:
@bess and @kelynch , I have the following JSON between DOE DOIs and the ARKs. This was outputted by [`dspace-osti`](https://github.com/pulibrary/dspace-osti/blob/main/Scraper.py). Hopefully this helps.
 
[redirects.txt](https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/files/9506784/redirects.txt)
I noticed that OSTI is also utilizing DataCite.  I went ahead and contacted DataCite to see if they had recommendations for how to request a URL changed on another prefix.

We may be able to just use the EZID API to update the ark URL redirects, which are what powers the OSTI DOI redirects. 
 I thought of this and discussed the possibility with @carolyncole, @bess, and @Twade968 and documented in this PR - https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/pull/412
Correct, updating the EZID may be the best approach. Keep in mind that the metadata stored on OSTI.gov is to the ARK and not the final landing URL/URI (I think).

I just tested that sending the publish event on an already published DOI will change the url if an updated url is sent.  I believe that updating the URL for the DOI will just work, once we are sending the appropriate URL. See https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_discovery/issues/328

princeton_ansible.title: Set tcp_keepalives params in postgres configuration

comments.body: This appears to be a solution to https://github.com/pulibrary/bibdata/issues/1959

I did a little digging on this one because I didn't understand it. Noting what I learned here:
You can set these values in Postgresql.
You can also set these values in the operating system, in `/etc/sysctl.conf`.
The two sets of settings have slightly different names.
- Time of inactivity before first keepalive request is sent, in seconds:
  - Postgresql: tcp_keepalives_idle
  - Sysctl.conf: tcp_keepalive_time
- Time between one keepalive request and the next, in seconds:
  - Postgresql: tcp_keepalives_interval
  - Sysctl.conf: tcp_keepalive_intvl
- Max number of keepalive requests sent before connection is considered broken:
  - Postgresql: tcp_keepalives_count
  - Sysctl.conf: tcp_keepalive_probes

Default value for all settings in Postgresql is `0` which picks up the OS setting. Consensus seems to be that it's best to set these in sysctl.conf. Is this something we want to set only on psql boxes, or across all infrastructure? @hackartisan's suggested settings would keep each connection alive for 5 and a half minutes (30 seconds before keepalives begin, then 10x30 seconds of keepalive requests) - does that seem like the right overall time?
Do any of our projects create long-running connections to postgresql that go dormant for more than 5 minutes but that we do not want to drop?

princeton_ansible.title: Postgresql TCP keepalive settings must match production needs
